entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q2-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment
  • Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates
  • Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER
  • Simplified Data Integration
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Catena-X Certification
  • SAP Innovation Award Wins: Harting and Matsumoto Precision
  • Customer Success Story: DMK
  • SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
  • Learning Journey: PCF Calculation

 

Streamlined Location Management with Cost Center Assignment

When integrating SAP Sustainability Footprint Management with various SAP systems, you often face a data challenge: Your warehouse in one SAP solution might be a facility in another or even a resource elsewhere. This inconsistency complicates footprint calculations, energy flow modeling, and linking environmental results to financials.

To address this and streamline and simplify the management of location data, we released the new Manage Locations application. This app serves as a single source for managing all locations, regardless of origin or business context. It addresses the need to reconcile and correlate locations that may have different semantics across multiple SAP solutions. With this new app you can:

  • View and manage all locations in one consolidated interface
  • Manually create locations or view those imported from other SAP modules
  • Easily distinguish between manually created and imported locations via the user interface
  • Navigate via links between imported location records and their corresponding system-generated system entries

Alternatively to replicating locations from source systems or creating them manually, you can upload location information via Excel files in the Import Master Data app. When importing, the software automatically generates corresponding location records that appear in the Manage Locations app – ensuring no duplicated or orphaned records. The locations itself are categorized into different location types, adding business context: Meter, Process Infrastructure, and Facility. Imported locations are automatically mapped to one of these three types. If a location type doesn’t match, it defaults to Facility. For modeling energy flows, you can now use these harmonized locations and resources as elements in your models. Hence, the creation of meters, process infrastructures, and facilities within the Model Energy Flows app is now managed exclusively via the new Manage Locations app – ensuring data consistency across apps.

Another major improvement is the possibility to assign cost centers for financial transparency and connecting carbon footprint results directly with your financial reporting. These assignments are time-dependent, ensuring correct mapping for each period. After calculating your organizational footprint, the Manage Footprint Results app shows the active cost center for that location – specifically, the cost center that is valid as of the calculation period’s start date, which is important if multiple cost centers are assigned to the location. Besides locations, cost centers can now also be assigned to energy sources in the Model Energy Flows app. This enables better tracking of spending related to energy use and maintenance, helping to analyze and manage energy costs more effectively.

Click the picture to start the video:

Manage Locations App (Click to start video)

To summarize, these enhancements bring you a centralized, consistent interface for all location data with improved usability and a simplified integration across various SAP systems. The flexible cost center assignment enables the linkage of environmental data to financial entities. This empowers smarter and holistic decision-making in sustainability management, moving further along the journey towards ledger-based carbon accounting with SAP Green Ledger. For all details, see Manage Locations on SAP Help.

 

Calculate Consumed Energy using Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates

A common challenge for calculating Scope 1 and 2 emissions is the timely availability of energy bills needed for accurately recording energy consumption. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management addresses this by introducing more flexibility in how energy data can be captured. Now, when creating energy sources, you can select your preferred method for recording energy consumption, with the two available options:

  • Actual Consumption from Energy Bills: Enter the actual quantities consumed as detailed on your energy bills (the most accurate method).
  • Estimates via Meter Readings and Planned Energy Consumption Rates: Add up amounts based on assigned meter readings and planned energy consumption rates, which allows you to work with estimates when bills are unavailable.

Select Recording of Energy Consumption

This new functionality isn’t limited to newly created energy sources. You can apply it to existing ones as well. However, it’s important to note that updating an energy source with this new logic doesn’t automatically trigger updates across all footprint inventories. If you edit the inventories that reference the updated energy source in their energy flow models, the system will recalculate using the newly selected consumption recording logic.

This release gives you the flexibility to maintain complete and more timely energy consumption records, improving the reliability of your sustainability data even when actual energy bills are delayed or not available at all. For more information, see the Energy Sources section under Model Energy Flows.

 

Default Emission Factors from UK DEFRA and EMBER

For calculating carbon footprints with no actual supplier or provider data available, it’s crucial to have access to reliable industry average data from Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) databases. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management provides you with the flexibility to upload respective data from any source into the Manage Emission Factors app. To simplify the setup for you and reduce manual efforts, we now added new default content, available for mapping your activities for calculating the respective footprints.

The data from UK Department for Energy Security and Net Zero and UK Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (UK DEFRA) includes emission factors for energy use, water consumption, waste disposal, recycling, and transport activities. There are datasets available for the years 2015 to 2024.

EMBER, an independent energy think tank, provides emission factors for electricity generation for over 200 geographies. The datasets comprise the years 2015 to 2023.

Click the picture to start the video:

Default Emission Factors in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management (Click to start video)

With those enhancements, you have access to additional reliable and diverse data sources for better environmental impact analysis and decision-making. For more information, see Using Default Emission Factor Data.

This new content complements the datasets from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) which were already added last year. And for the second half year we plan to add even more pre-configured emission factors from additional sources, further enhancing your carbon footprint calculation. The addition of emission factors was also one of the highest voted items on SAP Influence, requested by several customers and partners. Thanks to your valuable feedback, we’re constantly improving our product.

 

Simplified Data Integration

SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduced significant enhancements to how sustainability data is imported and managed, making processes more simple, efficient, and user-friendly. The tool leverages the sustainability data integration service to streamline data import from SAP systems, including SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP Environment, Health and Safety Management. This update eliminates many manual steps and unifies the process across systems. All changes are reflected in the updated SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Implementation Guide on SAP Help Portal.

With those enhancements, we’re also introducing the Manage Replications application. This new app allows you to configure and manage the replication of master data objects, such as products or suppliers, from multiple integrated SAP systems. Once replication is initiated through this app, imported data becomes visible in the Import Master Data app, simplifying subsequent data management tasks. The key benefits for you are:

  • Multi-source replication: Import master data from various source systems (for example fetch Products from SAP S/4HANA and Suppliers from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition).
  • Centralized management: Oversee and control all data replications from one place.
  • Improved data consistency: Ensures data is harmonized and consistent, provided the correct source systems are chosen for each data object.
  • Filter records: For some of the entities, like Products, you can filter the source data objects so only the ones which are relevant in your footprint calculation are replicated.

To use the Manage Replications app, users must be manually assigned the roles: SUS_Replication_Viewer or SUS_Replication_Expert. Find further information as well as all details on the new app in SAP Help: Manage Replications.

Manage Replications App

For existing customers, the following changes are required:

  • Switch to Manage Replications App: The previous method of importing master data directly within the Import Master Data app is discontinued for integrated source systems. The Import button has been removed, and all such imports must now be managed through the new Manage Replications app.
  • SAP EHS Management Integration: All emissions management activities and locations must now be imported via the Manage Replications app.
  • Replication Details: When replicating Suppliers or Emission Management Activities, each replication now performs a complete import – incremental or delta updates are no longer supported for these entities.

Those updates vastly improve the efficiency and governance of sustainability data management within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, offering you a more powerful, secure, and streamlined experience when handling master data from multiple integrated sources.

 

Other Release Highlights

The Monitor Plausibility Checks app displays reference details of the item, period, and measure value used as the baseline for creating relative plausibility alerts. This helps you assess how much actual results deviate from expected calculations. For more information, see Monitor Plausibility Checks. This is also a feature that was implemented after numerous customers requested it via SAP Influence.

A new Generate Records button in the Manage Purchased Products Footprints app allows you to manually generate records for purchased products and product groups that lack footprints. Progress is displayed during record generation, and users are notified if records need to be regenerated due to data updates, ensuring accuracy and control. Additionally, the UI in the related tabs now labels the AI-assisted mapping button as Generate Mappings Using AI. See Manage Purchased Product Footprints for more details.

We achieved significant performance improvements in cycle calculations, where a process's output becomes its own input. Previously, the runtime increased with the cycle's complexity. Now, calculations are done in-memory rather than relying on database access, greatly reducing calculation time and improving user efficiency.

SAP now offers real-time machine translation for documentation on the SAP Help Portal, including SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This increases the number of available languages, improving accessibility and availability of product information for users worldwide.

To help you with onboarding and using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we’re also constantly enhancing the product documentation on SAP Help. In the previous quarter, this included the following topics:

  • Energy carrier assignment per internal service confirmation: The new topic in the Energy Distribution Scenarios section explains two different methods for assigning energy to production documents using data from internal service confirmations, see Energy Carrier Assignment per Internal Service Confirmation.
  • Modeling consistent energy flows: Useful guidance on using energy elements in flow models and explanations on how different components are connected, see Modeling Consistent Energy Flows.
  • Energy distribution scenarios: The updated explanation details how energy consumption and distribution are modeled via the energy flows, using planned rates, meter data, or both, see Energy Distribution Scenarios.
  • Importing master data for Products using file upload: An example explains how to enter data for quantity conversions and quantity dimensions, see the section Example: Quantity Conversions and Dimensions in Products.
  • Data Inconsistencies: Guidelines on addressing these issues, see Business Transaction Data Consistency for details.
  • Delete imported business transaction data: More details on how to handle this process, see Deleting Business Transaction Data.

 

Catena-X Certification

In Q2, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management successfully was Catena-X certified by Cofinity-X, as the first carbon calculation software to receive this certification. Catena-X is the automotive industry’s open, collaborative data ecosystem, designed to facilitate secure and standardized data exchange across the entire value chain. With this certification, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management meets the rigorous calculation, interoperability, and data sovereignty standards required by Catena-X, enabling customers to seamlessly calculate and share trustworthy carbon footprint and sustainability data with partners, suppliers, and customers in the ecosystem. This not only supports regulatory and customer-driven transparency requirements but also paves the way for scalable decarbonization efforts in the automotive industry and beyond. By aligning with Catena-X, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management empowers organizations to participate confidently in cross-company sustainability initiatives within a rapidly evolving digital value network. With the integration to SAP Sustainability Data Exchange, carbon footprint data can be exchanged automatically and seamlessly.

 

Innovation Award Wins

We’re very proud to announce that two of our SAP Sustainability Footprint Management customers won the SAP Innovation Award 2025 in the Sustainability Hero category: Harting Technology Group and Matsumoto Precision!

Faced with the challenge of calculating carbon footprints for over 100,000 products across 14 factories, HARTING Technology Group needed a scalable, integrated solution. By becoming an early pilot customer of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, HARTING automated emissions tracking and achieved one-click carbon footprint calculations for 13,000 products – replacing a manual, time-consuming process. The solution, now live in three factories and expanding to all 14 by 2026, enables real-time, granular CO₂ data that supports HARTING’s “GreenLine” product label and helps meet stringent EU regulations like the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) and the Digital Product Passport. Thanks to this innovation, HARTING can now report that 85% of its packaging materials are recycled, and it has a clear path to achieving net-zero operations by 2030. This collaboration with SAP not only enhances transparency and compliance but also gives HARTING a competitive edge in customer bids – proving that sustainability and business success go hand in hand. Read the whole story here: HARTING - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

To address the growing demand for carbon transparency and operational efficiency, Matsumoto Precision implemented SAP S/4HANA alongside SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This combination gave the company real-time visibility into both product-level carbon emissions and profitability. With this data-driven approach, Matsumoto Precision was able to reduce its annual CO₂ emissions by 400 tons, increase productivity by 30 percent, and improve its operating profit margin by 3 percent. The factory now runs entirely on renewable energy, with on-site solar generation covering a significant portion of its needs. The implementation also empowered employees with real-time insights, leading to better decision-making and increased job satisfaction. Customers now receive verified carbon footprint data for each product, enhancing trust and supporting their own sustainability goals. In collaboration with Accenture, Matsumoto Precision even developed a generative AI tool that automates lifecycle flow diagrams, significantly reducing manual effort and streamlining emissions reporting. As CEO Toshitada Matsumoto put it, “With SAP S/4HANA and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, we make smarter, greener decisions while tracking and visualizing CO₂ emissions for each product. And with this clarity, we can enhance our brand value.” Matsumoto Precision’s journey is a compelling example of how small and mid-sized manufacturers can lead the way in sustainable innovation by embedding carbon intelligence into every layer of their operations. Read the full story here: Matsumoto Precision Co., Ltd. - SAP Innovation Awards 2025.

 

Customer Success Story: DMK

Germany’s largest dairy cooperative, DMK Deutsches Milchkontor GmbH, is leading the way in sustainable food production. Processing over 5.3 billion kilograms of milk annually, DMK is committed to reducing its environmental impact across the value chain. With ambitious climate goals – including a 42% reduction in Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2030 – DMK turned to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management to bring transparency and precision to its carbon accounting.

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, DMK transformed how it calculates and manages product-level emissions. The solution enabled the company to move beyond industry averages and instead use granular, actual data to assess the carbon footprint of its milk-based products. This shift provided DMK with unprecedented transparency and accuracy, particularly in understanding and reporting Scope 3 emissions from its upstream value chain, such as milk production and transportation.

The digitalization of carbon footprint management not only helped DMK meet regulatory requirements but also strengthened its ability to respond to customer demands for credible, verifiable sustainability metrics. With SAP’s expert support and a tailored pilot program, DMK integrated emissions data directly into its product lifecycle, enabling more strategic decision-making and targeted decarbonization efforts.

This collaboration has positioned DMK as a leader in sustainable dairy production, demonstrating how digital tools can drive real progress toward climate goals while enhancing trust and transparency across the value chain. Read the full story here: DMK: Identifying the carbon footprint of milk-based products on the way to decarbonizing the value chain.

 

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

SAP’s commitment to sustainability is integrated into its core mission of improving economic, social, and environmental outcomes while respecting planetary and human rights boundaries. SAP is actively using its own sustainability software solutions to meet environmental and social goals, demonstrating an “SAP runs SAP” and “customer zero” approach. By implementing tools like SAP Green Ledger, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management within its operations, SAP treats sustainability management with the same rigor as financial reporting.

As a user, SAP faces challenges similar to its clients: collecting and managing large volumes of sustainability data, ensuring compliance with evolving regulations, and integrating data systems across the organization and supply chain. By implementing its sustainability solutions and continuously refining them through hands-on experience, SAP gains valuable insights that help improve its products for clients. Key lessons from their internal adoption include: ensuring consistent emissions data collection, grounding projects within governance frameworks, expanding focus beyond carbon to other environmental factors, and establishing a multi-layer data architecture for effective collection, processing, and reporting. The rollout of these systems is iterative, enabling refinement and adaptation—especially important as regulatory requirements change, such as the new EU Omnibus package. Overall, SAP aims to provide actionable sustainability insights, streamline ESG reporting, and drive both internal and customer progress toward measurable sustainability outcomes. To learn more, read the news article from Matthias Medert, SAP’s global head of Sustainability: SAP Runs Its Own Solutions for Sustainability Goals.

A central piece of the SAP runs SAP Sustainability IT architecture is SAP Sustainability Footprint Management:

SAP Runs SAP Sustainability - IT Architecture

By implementing SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP has created a centralized and integrated platform to collect and calculate its corporate carbon emissions. The ambition is clear: to achieve full coverage of SAP’s carbon footprint through automated data collection and calculation. The software is much more than just a reporting tool, it acts as a central hub for emissions data, feeding into other SAP sustainability solutions such as the SAP Green Ledger, the SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and various internal systems. This enables comprehensive environmental impact analysis and supports regulatory compliance, while also informing strategic business decisions. Currently, SAP has already validated around 50% of its corporate carbon footprint within SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. This includes emissions from its own facilities like offices and data centers, as well as from shared infrastructure, cloud providers, and purchased goods and services.

The journey hasn’t been without challenges. At the outset, SAP faced difficulties in gathering and harmonizing data from multiple sources, each managed by different internal teams. Some of the data also required enrichment to be usable for sustainability purposes. However, through close collaboration between internal IT and business units, these hurdles were largely overcome, resulting in a more consistent and unified data flow.

Looking ahead, SAP aims to expand the system’s coverage to 100% of its corporate carbon footprint (excluding downstream emissions) before the planned business go-live in Q3. This milestone will involve five company codes and marks a significant step toward embedding sustainability deeper into SAP’s operations. All of this is being achieved through a continuous co-innovation process with SAP’s sustainability product engineering teams, demonstrating how SAP isn’t only building tools for others but also using them to lead by example. For all details, read the paper SAP runs SAP Sustainability: How to unlock the Power of Data on Sustainability Goals at Scale.

 

Learning Journey: PCF Calculation

The new Learning Journey Establishing the Product Carbon Footprint with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management is the first one that focuses on Product Carbon Footprint (PCF) calculation. The one-hour self-learning is as all our Learning Journeys free of charge and targets consultants and business users with advanced product knowledge. It explains distributing Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions to products via various methods and covers how to use the energy flow model and planned consumption rates for Scope 1 and 2, as well as additional allocation schemes for Scope 3 emissions. By completing this journey, users will be able to calculate and allocate emissions from business activities, energy use, and resources to products, leveraging dedicated models and production documents. You’ll also earn a Record of Achievement and a digital badge after successful completion and passing all quizzes.

Learning Journey: Establishing the Product Carbon Footprint with SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

This new PCF-centric Learning Journey complements our existing courses focusing on CCF calculation for beginners (Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Simple Configuration) and intermediates (Establishing Corporate Carbon Footprint Emissions with Advanced Configurations).

 

Additional Information

To get more insights about the integration between SAP S/4HANA, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Data Exchange, and SAP Green Ledger, you should check out the blog post Where finance and carbon unite by @PreethaB. With a practical example, she explains how to track carbon throughout business processes and incorporate sustainability into operations. By showing the complete workflow, it’s demonstrated how integrated solutions provide valuable sustainability insights, support informed decision-making, help achieve sustainability goals, and improve operations.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: How to Use the XML File from the SAP Activate Project Plan to Create a Microsoft Project File
entry.content:
Every year, we see thousands of downloads of the Project Plan from the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private roadmaps. The downloaded project plan folder includes both an Excel file and an XML file designed to help project managers quickly get started with their planning activities.

We always encourage teams to use SAP Cloud ALM for project planning, as it provides the latest content updates from SAP Activate Road maps and it includes powerful functionality similar to what you find in Microsoft Project. 

In Cloud ALM you can: 

  • Effectively run fit-to-standard workshops
  • Automatically assign team tasks
  • Centrally orchestrate test activities
  • Consistently deploy to production
  • Establish end-to-end traceability

Learn more about SAP Cloud ALM and check out this video introduction. 

Microsoft Project File Creation 

We frequently receive questions about how to create a Microsoft Project file using the XML file provided. While the folder includes a helpful "Read Me" document with step-by-step instructions, it can easily be overlooked. Recently, I received a couple feedback comments in SAP Activate road map viewer from customers regarding issues with the download not working. I responded to each one individually, but to make things easier, I'm sharing the steps directly in this blog so you can get your project plan ready in Microsoft Project with just a few clicks.

 

When you select “Download Project Plan,” (Step 1, 2 &3 in the below screenshot), the system generates a PM.230.zip file that will be saved on your machine. 
 
 
Inside this zip file, you’ll find a folder named “Microsoft Project files.” (Ste 4 & 5 below)
 
 

 

This folder contains a “Read Me” text file with instructions on how to access and open the MS Project files.
 
This blog covers the steps highlighted in the Read Me.txt file
 

 

 
In the Microsoft Project Files folder, you’ll find the .xml files for MS Project and can choose the relevant XML file (per transition scenario) and open it directly in MS Project.
 
Please Note: If you’re only seeing HTML links, please ensure you extract the entire zip file and check the “Microsoft Project files” folder as described.
 
Open Microsoft Project and select a new blank project. 
 

 

 

Select File --> Open --> find the xml file you want to use (per transition scenario) --> Import as a new project 
 

 

 

You should see the xml content loaded in the MS Project you created. 
 

 

 
Hope you find this blog useful, send me your questions in the comment section below or, provide feedback directly in road map viewer while viewing the content. Refer to my previous blog Providing Feedback in SAP Activate road map viewer.
 
Thank you for your continued engagement with SAP Activate!

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori – Organizing your My Home page
entry.content:
TL;DR – Tips and tricks for effectively demonstrating SAP Fiori as a functional consultant. Having a well-organized launchpad helps you run a successful demo. Most changes take seconds and can be adjusted before each demo.  These tips are based on observing consultants in fit-to-standard workshops on an SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 system, and working with them to improve their demo skills.

 Here are some pro-tips based on real-life experiences for effectively demonstrating SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA, based on experiences with functional consultants. These suggestions can help you present SAP Fiori to your business users and provide suggestions for your change management team.  In this blog series you will find:

  • Researching your process (coming)
  • Organizing your My Home page – this blog post
  • Navigating confidently
  • Showing extension possibilities (coming)

In most demonstrations the very first screen your users will see is the launchpad with the My Home for SAP S/4HANA page.  Having a well-organized My Home page sets a good first impression!

Here’s an example of a well-tailored My Home ready to run a Fit-to-Standard workshop based on SAP Signavio Best Practices Scope Item 1IU Consignment Stock.

A well-organized demo-ready My Home page

Below you will learn how to organize your My Home for SAP S/4HANA page for maximum effect, including:

  • Rapid intro to the main launchpad features
  • Check your language and region settings
  • Adjust the launchpad navigation bar to suit your demo
  • Choose Favorite Pages useful to your demo
  • Make the most of Favorite Apps
  • Adjust your My Home Settings for speed and relevance
  • Know the impact of authorizations
  • FAQ

Pro-tip: Most of these changes take seconds to make, so you can quickly adjust these settings before the start of each workshop.

Worth Knowing: The use case for the examples in this blog post is a Fit-to-Standard workshop based on SAP Signavio Best Practices Scope Item 1IU Consignment Stock – i.e. where the company stock is stored at the Customer’s site for convenience, for improved warehouse management, and/or for marketing purposes. The customer needs to track fill-up, issue, pick-up, and return of the stock.  This scope item involves a mix of 11 apps – some SAP Fiori apps & some GUI transactions – all launched from the SAP Fiori launchpad.

All examples in this blog post are taken from a SAP Cloud Appliance Library solution based on SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03. To access a similar system, read SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Create your SAP S/4HANA system in a fraction of the usual setup time

 

Pro-tips based on real-life experiences

The tips in this blog post are based on SAP Activate methodology Fit-to-Standard workshops at a recent customer project where consultants were demonstrating the latest SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 and higher.  All processes were demonstrated from the SAP Fiori launchpad. The consultants had a range of skills from very/somewhat familiar with SAP Fiori to brand new to SAP Fiori.  

For this customer, nearly 100 SAP Business Roles were activated and test users generated for each business role. For a handful of processes, 5 additional custom business roles were created.

Many of our consultants had 50 or more business roles assigned to their own user id.  This creates several challenges for both the consultants and the business user audience faced with:

  • A cluttered and disorganized My Home page
  • Too many tabs (spaces) in the navigation bar
  • Too many favorite apps
  • Irrelevant insight tiles/cards

Here’s a typical messy starting point: 

Typical poorly organized My Home page of a consultant

You will learn it’s quite easy to fix this!

 

Rapid intro to the main launchpad features

Make sure you know how to use the major launchpad features and can explain them.

It’s a good idea to check at the start of your demo if your audience is familiar with the SAP Fiori launchpad. If not, you should be able to explain the main features very quickly.

You can get a fast introduction by reviewing video Discover the Fiori launchpad [01:33]

 

Check your language and region settings

Check your date/time, decimal, and language settings are appropriate for your audience!

Hint: If you come from SAP ECC, this is the SAP Fiori equivalent to settings in transaction SU3.

If you are using a sandbox system – especially one that is based on Best Practice content – these may not be set correctly for your region. 

1. Open the User Actions menu (the top right most icon in the launchpad) and select Settings.

User Actions menu with Settings highlighted

2. In the Settings dialog, check your demo user’s Language and Region. 

Language and Region Settings

3. Make sure the date/time, decimal, language are set appropriately. 

Pro-tip: If your workshop involves multiple regions, remember to explain at the start of the demo which regional settings and time zone you are using for the demo!

In our workshops, the target audience often came from multiple regions – in some workshops there were people from Australia, Singapore, Canada, and the United States. Some people were onsite, and some attending virtually via Microsoft Teams calls. 

 

Adjust the launchpad navigation bar to suit your demo

Most business users would typically be granted around 5-6 spaces in their navigation bar. However, most consultants have been assigned dozens of spaces – this makes for a very confusing and very unrealistic start to your demo. 

You want your navigation bar to look simple and focused. Here’s a good example where the space tabs are organized in a logical order for the demo. 

Demo-ready navigation bar using spaces and pages

With the consignment stock demo the sequence of the tab supports the demo as follows:

  • Internal Sales - start the process in sales to fill-up the consignment stock
  • Inventory Management – to show the impact of consignment stock on inventory
  • Shipping - to show what happens as stock is issued
  • Billing – to show how the customer pays for the stock they use
  • Customer Returns – to end by showing what happens if a customer decides to return stock

Hint: Naturally you check inventory management at each stage of the process.  You’ll learn some pro-tips to navigate around in a future blog post of this series.

Adjusting your pinned spaces takes seconds – and helps your audience understand the flow – so this is a good adjustment to make before each demo session.

  1. Go to the navigation bar space personalization dialog (look for the stacked lines icon under the logo).
  2. Unpin All spaces.
  3. Pin only the spaces you need.
  4. Use drag and drop in the Pinned Spaces section to adjust the order of the space tabs to suit the logical flow.

Pin and Unpin features in the space personalization dialog

You will find more examples in video Changing the Sequences of Spaces [01:00].

For more options, refer to blog post Getting Started with Spaces and Pages

 

Choose favorite pages useful to your demo

To minimize navigation, you can add direct links to the pages as Favorite Pages on your My Home page.  You can use your Favorite Pages to navigate directly to the relevant page.

You can have a maximum of 8 favorite pages.

Pro-tip: There’s no minimum number of pages, however the default "you can add pages" message is quite prominent, so enabling a few favorite pages usually looks better.

Demo-ready pages section showing 2 relevant favorite pages

1. From the section title Pages, select the drop-down option and select Manage Pages. This opens the My Home Settings dialog on the Pages section.

You find Manage Pages in the Pages drop-down menu

2. Hide any pages you don’t need using the Show/Hide toggle (set to de-emphasized).

3. Add the pages you want to include using the Show/Hide toggle (set to emphasized).

4. Close the My Home Settings dialog.

Pro-tip: In the My Home Settings > Pages section if you are assigned many pages,  you can use the search to find the page you want to mark as favorites.

My Home Settings - Pages section highlighting the search and show/hide toggles

Pro-tip: Analytics pages are useful to include as favorite pages because:

  • They often include dynamic analytical tiles that showing numbers or charts. These  give the business user a quick heads-up on whether everything is fine, or whether they need to drill-down to the related report to gain further insights and decide what actions to take.
  • They are typically not the first page in the space – so making them a favorite page can save a few clicks.

Sales Analytics page includes dynamic KPI tiles for a quick heads-up

Hint: Don’t bother including Overview pages that you can reach with a single click on the space in the navigation bar. There’s no advantage in making these a favorite Page.

 

Make the most of Favorite Apps

If you are not entirely happy with the flow on your spaces and pages you may want to set up some Favorite Apps on your My Home page. This is especially useful to group tasks that are scattered across several different pages or classic UIs (such as GUI transactions) that may not be included any page.  

You can group your favorite apps and give them a useful name and assign a color. The group folder automatically shows how many apps are in the group.  Here's an example of a demo-ready Apps section with the tab bar highlighted. The main consignment apps (i.e. SAP Fiori apps and classic UIs) have been grouped into a secdtion named "Consignment Fill-Up Issue & Return".

Demo-ready favorite apps section

Selecting the group shows the apps within it, and these have been organized in a logical left-to-right, top-down order. 

Demo-ready group of apps well-named and sorted

Pro-tip: The group name can be quite long, which is useful for introducing unfamiliar terminology. For example, in our workshops our audience were used to the term “Customer Invoices” while in standard SAP these are known as “Billing Documents”, so to reduce confusion the name for the group of apps can be named “Customer Invoices (Billing Documents)”. You can see this in the example demo-ready Apps section above.

Pro-tip: During your preparation, run through the process once using the Search on Apps to find your apps. Once you have run the process once, then all the apps will be in the Apps > Recently Used section and you can use the “…” context menu on each app to add the app to your Favorite Apps.

Example of adding an app to Favorites from Recently Used: 

Add favorite app from recently used

To add favorite apps in the Apps section:

  1. On tab Recently Used use the context menu to “Add to Favorites App”.  Hint: This option will only show if the app is NOT already in your favorite apps.
  2. On tab Favorites, drag and drop apps onto each other to create a group.
  3. Assign the group a name and a color.
  4. Drag and drop more favorite apps onto the group to add them to the group.
  5. Select the group to open it.
  6. Use drag and drop within the group to organize the apps in your preferred sort order.

For more examples, review video My Home in SAP S/4HANA – section on adding favorite apps is [02:04 – 03:10]

 

Adjust your My Home Settings for speed and relevance

You can use the My Home Settings to further adjust your home page for the demo. Once again this takes seconds.

User Actions menu highlighting My Home Settings

Pro-tips: Adjust your My Home Settings as follows:

  • Leave the To-Do’s section available as delivered. If you have an approval task or a situation notification, a To-Do will appear automatically. You can click on the task to go straight to the My Inbox or My Situations apps. If these are not part of your scenario, a pleasant “You have no tasks” message is shown.
  • Restrict the number of Insight Tiles and Insight Cards. 
  • Aim for no more than 3 insight tiles and 3 insight cards.  These dynamic tiles are calling services every time you return to the launchpad, so every unnecessary tile/card slows your demo down.
  • To avoid confusing your audience, make sure any insight tiles/cards you enable are relevant to your demo.
  • You can use the search to find the tiles by name

If you have an audience where you need to keep it very simple:

  • Consider hiding sections that are not needed.  
  • You can adjust the order of the My Home sections if that helps your demo flow.

Example of the Insight Cards section in My Home Settings. The search for cards is highlighted.

Settings for insight cards highlighting the search

For more examples, review video My Home in SAP S/4HANA :

  • The section on adjusting insight tiles/cards is [03:11 – 04:04]
  • The section on adjusting sections is [04:05 – 04:45]

 

Know the impact of authorizations in a real-life scenario

I’ve seen many consultants assume their experience is the same as the business user even though they have given themselves the “all access” SAP_ALL + SAP_NEW profiles and assigned themselves dozens of business roles.

There are many areas that are controlled by authorizations in SAP Fiori.

For the My Home for SAP S/4HANA you should know that:

  • A user can only see tiles/links/cards if they are authorized to launch the target app
    • The App Support tool tracks which cards have been hidden due to authorizations in the SAPUI5 Log Messages section. Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – New improvements in App Support
  • For dynamic tiles/cards – those showing numbers or charts – the user’s view is restricted by their data authorizations. E.g. If a card shows the number of open Sales Orders then:
    • A user with SAP_ALL will see the total number of Open Sales Orders in the system.
    • A user with access to only 1 Sales Organization will only see the total number of Open Sales Orders for their Sales Organization.

Hints: Data authorizations in SAP S/4HANA work in a similar way to SAP ECC, with one major advantage:

  • In SAP ECC, a program would extract all data and then remove any data the user is not authorized to view.
  • In SAP S/4HANA, the user’s authorizations are applied to the database extraction directly. This means apps only extract data the user is authorized to see.  This is more secure and more performant. 

 

Bad habits to break

Using Favorite Apps to avoid using spaces and pages.

There is often more value in going to a space/page – particularly where analytics tiles show dynamic values that can indicate whether the user even needs to drilldown.

Spaces and pages show what on-system tasks are expected of this user as part of their day-to-day. It emphasizes most important starting points for processes. Very easy to tailor.

 

Creating a “bathroom wall” of dozens of tiny app tiles in Favorite Apps

I have seen some consultants with more than 50 favorite apps – and it just looks messy and confusing. Instead to minimize the tiles, use the grouping feature explained above to indicate apps belonging to different parts of your process. You can assign a colour to each group to easily distinguish which groups belong to which workshop or process.

 

Cool stuff to show

Consider reducing white space on the page

You can use Edit Current Page in the top right-most User Actions menu to adjust the tile sizes on the page. Consider changing any tile that you don’t need into a smaller tile size such as a flat tile or link.  Be aware that these sorts of changes can easily done for all users in the role later in your project via the WYSIWYG editor in app F4512 Manage Launchpad Pages.  For how to do this for your demo, review video Personalizing Pages.

More videos in blog post Getting Started with Spaces and Pages

You can share your My Home settings with other users

You can use My Home Settings > Advanced to access the export / import features to share your settings with someone else, for example, when training up a new person.

This is somewhat like the SAP ECC option to upload/download favorite transactions from your SAP GUI user menu.  Export/import My Home Settings has some advantages in that:

  1.  You can pick what you want to share
  2. The SAP Fiori launchpad will hide any apps the target user is not authorized to launch

Example showing My Home Settings Advanced – Export tab.

My Home Settings - Advanced features

 

FAQ

Where should analytics be placed for best effect?

It all depends on how frequently you use them. You want them easy to access but not in your way or slowing down your launchpad or your navigation. So:

  • If you need to check them multiple times per day, place them as Insight Tiles/Cards on your My Home page
  • If you check them once per day, include them in the first “Overview” page of a space.
  • If you would check them less than once per day, place them on any other page of a space that makes sense. 

Hint: You will often find that predefined spaces of SAP Business Roles include an analytics page for less frequently used analytics.  For example, the Internal Sales Representative has a page called “Sales Analytics”.

Example of pages in the Internal Sales space highlight the page Sales Analytics

 

Should I show the context-sensitive help?

Yes, you can use the Help “?” icon in the launchpad shell bar to show the help.  When you are on the My Home page, this takes you to the tutorials Working with the Launchpad and Working with Apps tutorials.

Pro-tip: Currently these tutorials are managed in SAP Enable Now. These will likely be moved to new tutorials in SAP WalkMe in future.

 

Should I use Adapt UI on the home page?

No! Leave it alone! That’s for the administrator to adjust the default My Home page settings for all users. If you change that you might upset your colleagues demonstrations… and they won’t be happy!  Don’t worry – there’s plenty of other places you will get to use Adapt UI … but that’s for a future blog post.

 

Hey! I noticed the favorite apps sometimes take on the color of the favorite pages?

Correct! Yes by default the favorite app icon will take on the color of the favorite page it comes from. If the favorite app icon is grey it doesn’t match to any of your favorite pages.  You can select the context menu on the favorite app to change the color.

 

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You’ll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG and Customer Care team.

entry.title: Currency Changeover needs on productive SAP S/4 HANA On-Prem and Private Cloud Environment
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog outlines the typical business triggers that drive the need for a currency changeover in a productive SAP S/4HANA environment. It also highlights the possible realization methodology to support such transformations.

General Business Triggers

Currency conversion requirements are usually driven by strategic, regulatory, or compliance-related events that necessitate a change in the currency model of your SAP system. These scenarios often arise during financial transformations, mergers, organizational restructurings, or statutory reporting changes. Common business triggers include:

  • Legal Currency Change in a Country: A country may mandate a change in its local currency due to reasons such as joining a monetary union (e.g., adoption of the Euro), experiencing hyperinflation, or undergoing political or economic reform.
  • Extension of Reporting Currency: The current ERP system may be configured for only one local reporting currency. Due to requirements such as hyperinflation, currency instability, or IFRS reporting, businesses may need to enable an additional parallel local currency in their productive environment.
  • Group Currency Alignment for Global Operations: Companies operating across multiple countries under different subsidiaries may need to establish a unified group reporting currency to align financial reporting across application modules.
  • Change in Corporate Headquarters/ Group Structure/ Merger & Acquisition: A shift in the corporate headquarters or the inclusion of a new entity with a different group currency may require changes to the existing group currency setup for consolidated financial reporting.
  • Parallel Valuation of Inventories in different valuation methods: Organizations may need to enable transfer pricing and support parallel inventory valuations to gain financial insights from different valuation perspectives and meet reporting requirements.

Possible Scenarios of Currency Changeovers in SAP S/4HANA System

Currency changeover requirements in an SAP S/4HANA system can arise in various business scenarios depending on the reporting, legal, or strategic needs. Below are some common scenarios with illustrative examples:

Scenario 1: Change of First Local Currency Across All Company Codes

A requirement to change the primary local currency (currency type 10) consistently in a company code using a fixed exchange rate.

  • Example: Company code 1000 is currently using INR as the first local currency. The requirement is to change it to USD.

Scenario 2: Introduction of a Parallel Currency with Valuation View

Business requires an additional parallel currency integrated across FI and ML, associated with a specific valuation view (e.g., 11, 12, 31, or 32) to support group or profit center valuation.

  • Example: For company code 1000, there is a need to introduce Group Currency in Group Valuation as a parallel valuation view.

Scenario 3: Introduction of a Freely Definable Currency

The need to add a freely definable currency within the FI application module to support additional parallel reporting.

Refer to SAP Note 2334583 – Introduction of new currencies / currency types in SAP S/4HANA, which describes how to manage new currencies via the Manage Currencies Cockpit.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the requirement is to introduce a freely defined currency for additional reporting.

Scenario 4: Changeover of Group Currency (Client Currency)

Changing the Group Currency (currency type 30) across the system consistently—for example, from EUR to USD. This may involve replacement across all application modules, such as FI, CO, and ML, where group currency is already in use.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the group currency needs to be changed from USD to EUR.

Scenario 5: Introduction of Group Currency in Systems Without Prior Usage

In systems where Group Currency was not used historically—such as ECC systems using CO currency types 10/20—the migration to S/4HANA may result in the CO currency (now known as "Global Currency" - Refer SAP note 2344012 - Currencies in Universal Journal) occupying the KSL field group in the ACDOCA table. Introducing group currency in such a case requires consistent integration across all modules, including FI and CO, and overwriting existing KSL values where necessary.

  • Example: For company code 1000, the requirement is to introduce Group Currency as both the Controlling Area Currency and an FI-integrated currency (BSEG level).

Scenario 6: Organizational restructure (change Controlling area currency)

Organizational Restructuring such as a merging multiple controlling areas into a single, unified structure to support centralized management may require the alignment of controlling area currencies to ensure consistency across the organizational hierarchy.

Example: There are 3 Controlling Areas 1000, 2000, 3000 with varying currency settings. Requirement is to merge the controlling areas 1000 and 2000 into 3000.

 Scenario 7: Activation of Universal Parallel Accounting (UPA):
To comply with multiple accounting standards, organizations may seek to activate Universal Parallel Accounting, which requires alignment of existing currency configurations and pre-requisites.

Example: For company code 1000, 0L and 1L ledger is active with company code currency (LC1) and group currency (LC2) and a freely defined currency. Requirement is to activate business function UPA and align the currencies and ledger across application module -FI, FI-AA and ML.

Realization Methodology

Once a company code is productive or live with transactional data, changing the configured currency must not be performed by simply transporting the modified configuration. Moving configuration changes without transforming the already posted documents can lead to data inconsistencies in the live system, potentially causing critical disruptions in business processes—such as clearing open invoices.

To make changes in currency settings, both the configuration and the associated transactional data must be transformed. For transforming existing posted documents, the SAP DMLT Currency Conversion Service is required. For more information, refer to the Currency Conversion Solution Brief.

Such data transformations in a live production system demand a highly precise and controlled changeover, ensuring consistency at the database level and seamless continuity of SAP software operations. Therefore, every relevant business scenario should be carefully reviewed in the system, considering current configurations and customizations across all connected application modules.

SAP DMLT offers a technical feasibility study to outline system data dependencies and prerequisite conditions. This is followed by a detailed customer workshop. The realization of the transformation requirement is delivered under a separate professional consulting contract and executed as a project.

The overall delivery process is broadly divided into two parts:

1. Pre-Qualification of Requirement

It is essential to pre-qualify the business requirement to ensure the right-fit transformation solution is offered. This starts with gathering preliminary details about the business requirement and application usage within the system through a technical questionnaire, available at Data Unification & Harmonization.

Based on the responses, SAP can propose a feasibility study to assess the system, evaluate overall complexity, and deliver a detailed proposal. This assessment typically takes around two weeks, including the deployment of analysis tools in the system.

An SAP solution expert will perform the system assessment and present the key insights during a customer workshop session. This is followed by the provision of commercial details through the regional SAP Market Unit.

2. Project Delivery

Depending on the complexity of the engagement, the required number of mock execution cycles will be determined during the scoping phase. In general, data transformation projects of this nature involve a minimum of three mock cycles before the production data cutover. The purpose of a mock execution is to simulate the complete production data conversion, validate the results, and estimate the overall downtime required for the production system. Each mock execution cycle includes several phases, which can be broadly classified as follows:

2.1 Technical Preparation Phase of Add-On (Uptime):

These types of transformation capabilities are deployed into the customer system as a separate add-on, delivered as transportable content. The mock execution system should be a recent copy of the production system, with hardware configuration closely matching that of the production environment. Once the tool content is deployed, the technical preparation phase begins, during which SAP DMLT experts prepare the transformation tool. This phase typically takes 2–3 weeks and includes uptime activities and the generation of technical programs for the relevant table-fields.

2.2 Data Conversion Phase (Downtime):

After the uptime preparatory activities are completed, the agreed business downtime begins. During this period, currency conversion is performed directly at the database table-field level. All relevant currency values (currency key/amount) are updated in the respective parallel currency fields in affected application areas (e.g., FI-GL, FI-AA, ML, CO etc) using a fixed exchange rate. Such conversions are applied retroactively for all fiscal years and Go-Live is not bound by a key date.

2.3 Post-Conversion Data Reconciliation Phase (Downtime):

Currency conversion may result in rounding differences, especially in accounting areas where specific rules apply—such as clearings that must net to zero. It is generally recommended to ignore rounding differences from previous fiscal years and reconcile only the current fiscal year. For business continuity, reconciliation of current fiscal year data is performed immediately after the conversion to mitigate the impact of rounding differences and to synchronize data across tightly integrated modules such as FI, CO, and ML.

2.4 Post-Processing Testing Phase (Downtime):

Once the reconciliation phase is complete, the transformed system is handed over to the customer’s IT/application team for a sanity check during downtime. Upon successful completion of the sanity check, the transformed system is reopened for normal business operations.

How to Engage with SAP

If your business requirement involves transforming any currency-related aspect in a live, productive SAP S/4HANA system, you should engage with the SAP Data Management and Landscape Transformation (DMLT) consulting team.

There are two primary ways to initiate the engagement:

  1. Create a Support Incident
    Submit an incident via the SAP ONE Support Launchpad under the component:
    CA-LT-SRV (Landscape Transformation Services)
  2. Contact via Email
    Reach out directly to the DMLT Global Consulting Experts by emailing-  sap_dmlt_gce@sap.com

The SAP DMLT team will guide you through the pre-assessment process, feasibility evaluation, and project-based service engagement tailored to your specific system and transformation needs.

Reference SAP OSS Notes:

3476589 - Parallel Currency Transformations in S/4HANA

481938 - System Landscape Optimization Services

3229024 - S/4HANA Local Currency Changeover - Central Note

3334743 - S/4HANA / SFIN 720/730: Is a subsequent implementation and activation of a Profit Center Valuation and/or Group valuation possible?

2882025 - Multiple valuation approaches/transfer prices in SAP S/4HANA, on-premise edition

175758 - Deactivating transfer prices/multiple valuation approaches

Other References:

Blog Post: DMLT- Currency Conversion Services Overview and Insights

Currencies Managed in Parallel in the Universal Journal | SAP Help Portal

Disclaimer: This blog is intended only for knowledge sharing about currency conversion service on SAP S/4 HANA which might help customer in their landscape transformation requirements. It should not be considered as guideline for performing such transformation services on their own in the SAP landscape. Any data transformation efforts should be thoroughly assessed in consultation with qualified subject matter experts, supported by a comprehensive system study, and aligned with the appropriate approvals from your auditors.

entry.title: Amazon Seller Central SAP S4 HANA integration Part 2 - Fulfilled by Merchant
entry.content:
Banner Image - SAP S4 HANA and Amazon FBM Integration Explained.

Just incase you landed on this directly, this is a second chapter of how you can integrate SAP S4 with Amazon Seller Central if you are operating under Fulfilled by Merchant model. In the first part - How to get started with SAP S4 HANA and Amazon Seller Central integration,  I discussed how I started building SAP Integration with Amazon Seller Central. The challenges and difficulties in getting and maintaining Amazon developer ID. We also talked about various Amazon API structure and various Amazon merchant models.

Understanding Amazon FBM process using SAP S4 SAP Sales and Distribution (SD) cycle

In this post, we are going to be talking about how you can integrate Amazon in case of Fulfilled by Merchant (FBM) scenario. I assume that most of the audience here would be well versed in SAP Sales and Distribution. If you are too, FBM is a drop ship kind of arrangement with Amazon, where customers come and place an order on Amazon, the shipping happens from Merchant’s warehouse.

What is Amazon FBM Model

Amazon then settles account with Merchant on a periodic basis. If you are with me so far, you got the important gist of the process. Let me show you how you can integrate FBM process using standard SAP SD cycle.

Let us break the integration into individual components.

  • Merchandize and catalog sync
  • Inventory synchronization
  • Amazon Order syncing with SAP
  • Out going delivery and tracking number
  • Invoice generation and A/R Posting
  • Return and refunds
  • Financial reconciliation between SAP and Amazon

A. Syncing merchandise with Amazon Seller Central Account

You may be selling only a part of your offerings on Amazon. Making a neat store with a proper tree structure and products assigned to them is of course the first step in getting started.

This is often done manually. Product information is enriched with proper images, description, related items for cross sell, specifications and more. See below Apple's store on Amazon with categories neatly laid out. 

Apple's Amazon Store with Categories and Sub-Categories

A key link to SAP’s material master and Amazon’s listing is the ASIN number. There are several ways to maintain ASIN numbers within SAP.

  • Text with Material
  • Custom table
  • Customer Material Info records
  • Unused field in Material Master

Customer material info records is the the cleanest way to do so. This is so because to be able to run SD cycle, Amazon has to be created as a business partner within SAP.

Maintaining Material Information in Customer Material Info Records with ASIN Numbers

 

It must be noted that the listings must be accurate and any orders placed for an item you have discontinued and are not being able to fulfill is dealt ruthlessly by Amazon. This reflects into your ratings and also search rankings.

B. Inventory Synchronization

You have to let Amazon know how much of each ASIN you have in stock ( ATP quantity). This becomes so crucial that it can make or break your Amazon store.

Syncing ATP Quantities with Amazon is a must for FBM Merchants.

As I mention that any orders placed on Amazon, if unfulfilled by merchant brings you down several notches and gives your closest competitor to rank above you.

Remember that SAP is your system of records. All B2B, EDI, Direct to Consumer orders being fulfilled centrally from the application. Each B2B order can change ATP across SKUs considerably.

So in essence, there are only two ways to deal with this situation.

  • Highly efficient integration which updates the inventory quantities several times a day.
  • Creating a separate plant or storage location exclusively for Amazon orders.

Another dimension to inventory sync is multi location stock.

If your inventory is spread across multiple warehouses in different regions, it’s best to sync these stock levels to Amazon. Amazon uses its intelligence then to calculate the estimated delivery time when customer sees the product. Receiving the product in 6 days versus 2, could be the single deciding factor for him to place order to browse other merchants.

 

C. Syncing Amazon FBM orders into SAP S4

The single most important aspect of this sync for all merchants is getting Amazon FBM Orders into their ERP, as efficiently as possible. This helps them get a window to be able to pick pack and ship the goods from the respective warehouse and let Amazon know the shipping details. 

In my experience working with several Amazon customers, a successful and optimized Amazon order in SAP should have the following key elements.

  • Amazon Order Number - I use PO number field for the same.
  • Shipping address - This not only ensures accurate shipping but also correct tax calculation. Remember that Amazon collects the tax on your behalf and it should match SAP’s calculation.
  • Bill to - This will be always Amazon for you.
  • Amazon Fees and Charges - You should have each Amazon fees and charges at the line item as mapped conditions type. Remember that some condition type can be statistical. For example the tax Amazon collected. If you do this part correct, the net amount payable by Amazon will match what it shows on your Amazon merchant portal. This I would say is the litmus test for orders synced.

Amazon Fees and Charges must be mapped to Condition Types within orders for better concilliation

  • Product and Quantities - Each ASIN must be converted to respective material numbers.

Litmus Test for Amazon Order Synced with SAP is that Net Amount must match what it shows as Payable on Amazon Portal

D. Outgoing Delivery and Tracking details

Amazon orders being shipped out of warehouse are usually small parcels. When PGI is done for these orders, tracking number should be related back to Amazon. Amazon notifies the end customer about the shipping details.

Amazon expects high operational efficiency from the merchants, specially the ones under FBM model.

Shipping goods as early as possible is really important for FBM Merchants

Hence, orders must ideally be shipped the same day, or even better within few hours.

This again calls for efficient and bi-directional integration.

While merchants may ship the goods in a timely manner, they are responsible for a timely delivery too. Hence any carrier delay also affects them adversely.

While this may seem unfair, there is a solution which Amazon offers around this. Amazon Veeqo is Amazon’s new acquisition which helps FBM merchant reduce their shipping cost as well as de risk them from carrier delays. Hence if a FBM merchant use Veeqo, any carrier delay doesn’t affect their ratings.

Bill of Lading is a good placeholder for storing tracking number for Outgoing Deliveries

E. Invoice

Interestingly, vendor invoice is not something Amazon is interested in getting. However for completeness of the process, merchants need to post SD Invoice when then post accurate receivables.

F. Return and Refunds

Amazon’s customer service and return policies are exceptional. When a customer returns goods, merchants need to raise a RMA. When goods are received at their end, Amazon issues them a credit.

In this case, a return order must be created in SAP with an inbound delivery and Post Goods Return followed by credit memo. The amount must match the respective line item in the original order.

G. Payment reconciliation

Amazon usually has a 2 week settlement cycle. This is amount paid for 2 week of sales net of returns. Given the volume of transactions, it becomes difficult to do it manually. A payment reconciliation report like the one below ease this entire process.

Why your Amazon settlement looks different from A/R shown in SAP

Despite doing the above integration, you may still find some differences in the amount you expected versus what Amazon paid you. This is so because there are some non order related, account level charges that may have been applied.

Some of them include any promotional event that you may have run with Amazon. Amazon also keeps a margin, some sort of deposit for every merchant. This margin safeguards Amazon to fulfill its commitment to customers on case merchant goes out of business. The margin amount d fluctuates as business transaction grows and hence adjustment may be required.

A few manual Adjustments may be needed despite integration

The good thing is that this is not usual or monthly phenomenon. Also these can be adjusted with few manual postings.

Without integration this entire reconciliation becomes manual and tedious.

Frequently asked questions

Here are some frequently asked questions regarding FBM questions in general and its integration with SAP in particular.

1. What is FBM and how is it different from FBA?

FBM stands for Fulfilled by Merchant. In this model, you (the seller) are responsible for storing, packing, and shipping the products when a customer places an order on Amazon.
On the other hand, FBA (Fulfilled by Amazon) means Amazon takes care of storing and shipping your products from its own warehouses.

2. How does the integration process differ for FBM?

In FBM, since the seller handles fulfillment, the integration focuses on syncing orders, inventory, deliveries, tracking details, and payment reconciliation between Amazon and SAP. You’re also expected to respond quickly to new orders and keep inventory up to date to avoid penalties from Amazon.

3. Is the integration approach different between SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC?

The core logic remains similar, but S/4HANA offers improved capabilities—like better data structures and more streamlined APIs—which can make the integration smoother. However, both require proper mapping of orders, products (ASINs), and financial data.

4. Can I consolidate Amazon orders into a single SAP order?

It’s not recommended. Each Amazon order should be created as a separate sales order in SAP. This ensures better tracking, accurate taxation, shipping, and proper return/refund processing.

5. Why is financial reconciliation so important?

Even after syncing all the order details, Amazon might deduct fees or hold a margin at the account level. Without regular reconciliation between Amazon reports and SAP receivables, these mismatches can cause accounting issues and missed revenue.

6. What is Amazon Veeqo and how can it help FBM sellers?

Veeqo is a shipping and inventory tool by Amazon, especially useful for FBM sellers. It helps reduce shipping costs and protects your account ratings from delays caused by third-party carriers. If the delay is on the courier side and you’re using Veeqo, Amazon won’t penalize you.

7. What is multi-location inventory and why is it important?

If you store inventory across different warehouses, syncing stock levels with Amazon helps customers see more accurate delivery timelines. For example, a buyer may prefer a seller who can deliver in 2 days versus 6. This improves chances of making a sale.

8. How do I link my SAP materials to Amazon listings?

You need to match each product’s ASIN (Amazon Standard Identification Number) with its corresponding Material Number in SAP. The cleanest way to do this is by using Customer Material Info Records in SAP, especially if Amazon is set up as a customer in your system.

9. How often should inventory be synced with Amazon?

Ideally, multiple times a day. Amazon expects real-time inventory updates to avoid overselling. If that's hard to manage, you could also dedicate a separate plant or storage location for Amazon orders to simplify tracking and syncing.

10. Do I need to send invoices to Amazon?

No, Amazon doesn’t ask for your invoices. But you still need to create and post invoices in SAP so your books are accurate and receivables are tracked properly.

11. What happens if I can’t fulfill an Amazon order?

Amazon is strict about fulfillment. If you fail to ship an order, your ratings and rankings take a hit—which can reduce your visibility and sales. That’s why tight integration and up-to-date inventory are critical.

12. How are returns and refunds handled in SAP?

When a customer returns a product, Amazon issues a credit. On your end, you should create a return order in SAP, do the Post Goods Receipt, and generate a credit memo—all while matching the original order details to keep records clean.

entry.title: Controlling and Scheduling the Production Using the Work Center Formula Parameter
entry.content:
Business Requirement

Company X wants to determine the duration or cost of operation required to produce a given product depending on factors like work center or tool.  

Company X uses a multiplier called the efficiency factor to the standard execution time, which varies depending on the age of the tools used or weather conditions, etc. They want to execute the process in their SAP Cloud ERP. 

Solution at High Level 

This solution focuses on calculating the execution time of an operation based on the efficiency factor
defined during the creation/updation of production routing. The multiplier that Company X uses is created as a custom field (called YY1_EFF_FACTOR) in Production Routing.

Steps to follow:

1. Access the Custom Fields app from the SAP Fiori launchpad.

2. Choose Add Fields to create a custom field.

3. In the New Field popup, set the Business Context to Manufacturing: Bill of Operations  Operation (PP_BILLOFOPERATIONS_OPERATION)

4. Set the field type to Quantity with Unit, as no other Business context or field types are supported for Work Centre Formula Parameters.

5. Once the required data is entered, choose Create and Edit. 

6. On the  General Information tab, take note of the Field Component Name ending with the suffix ‘_PPO’. This suffix is used to map the custom field to a parameter. 

7. On the User Interfaces tab, enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant SAP GUI screens, CDS Views, and Services. 

8. Enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant business scenario. Enable Routing to Production Order on Operation Level for Discrete Manufacturing.

9. Navigate back to Custom Field work list page.

10. Search for EFF_FACTOR. Select EFF_FACTOR for business context Manufacturing: Order Operation (PP_ORDER_OPERATION).

11. On the User Interfaces tab, enable the custom field’s usage for the relevant SAP GUI screens, CDS Views, and Services.

12. Create a workcenter formula parameter ZPP in the Define Parameters activity (ID: 102242). In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. For more information, see also Configuration Environment of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

13. Create the parameter with origin 8 (Custom Field from Operation). Fill in all the necessary data, leaving the ‘Field Name’ field blank. 

14. Once the parameter is created, create a WKC formula where the SAP standard parameter SAP_01 is multiplied by ZPP to calculate costs in the Define Formulas for Work Centers activity (ID: 102002). In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities. 

15. Once the parameter is created and formula defined, map the newly created custom field to Workcenter formula parameter. Use the Mapping Custom Tasklist Operation Fields to Work Center Formula Parameters configuration activity (ID: 106627) to map the fields. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the configuration activities.

16. Therefore, the creation of the work center formula parameter, definition of the formula, and mapping of the work center parameter to the routing operation custom field are complete.
The next step will be to either create a new work center according to the business scenario or update the existing work center with the newly created work center formula.

17. In the work center, use the newly created work center formula parameter under capacities, scheduling, and costing as per the business need. 

Capacity:

Scheduling:

Costing:

18. For production routing, you can add new operations or update the same operation with a new work center having the newly created work center formula.

Change shown for routing operation 0060:

19. In the custom fields, EFF_FACTOR is visible, and we can enter some efficiency factor into it.

20. Create Production Order for same material.

21. Navigate to Operation Overview.

22. Note the set-up duration.

23. Come back to Routing and change EFF_FACTOR to 20.

24. Schedule the created PO for the same operation. You will notice a change in setup duration due to a change in EFF_FACTOR in the routing.

25. Similarly, in Production Order, change the EFF_FACTOR to 30.

26. Before rescheduling, note the set-up duration.

After reschedule, the duration changes based on the change in EFF_FACTOR.

By following these steps, Company X can effectively streamline its production processes, ensuring efficiency and cost-effectiveness. Embracing SAP Cloud ERP not only enhances operational accuracy but also empowers the company to adapt swiftly to changing conditions.

entry.title: Navigating the BP transaction Authorizations in S/4HANA : SAP Security Experts Guide
entry.content:
General Overview

The Business Partner (BP) transaction is the central tool for managing customer and vendor master data in SAP S/4HANA. For many customers, this represents a transition from older transactions like XK01, FK01, and FD01. This change is part of the core data model redesign in S/4HANA, aimed at consolidating customer and vendor information into a single, unified repository. By doing so, it eliminates data redundancy and streamlines business processes. This approach is often also referred to as Customer-Vendor Integration (CVI).

This shift has many SAP Security consultants scratching their heads. The consolidated transaction called BP in S/4HANA combines functionality from over 60 legacy transactions into one powerful master transaction. While efficient, This simplification introduces a lot of complexity — particularly for security.

When you check the SU24 data for the BP transaction, you'll find it can include anywhere from 20 to 80 authorization objects. While this extensive list provides fine-grained control over access—which is great from a security standpoint—it can also be overwhelming. Assigning the BP transaction to a PFCG role often means suddenly facing the task of maintaining values for 30 or more authorization objects, which few enjoy dealing with.

Another challenge with the BP transaction is that, despite having a large number of authorization objects available to control access, many of these checks are inactive by default. As a result, the transaction appears to offer granular control, but in reality, it lacks many essential authorization checks—making it difficult to enforce precise access restrictions.
